page.title: 05PUBLIC HEALTH
page.content: Two of the most significant events in {Kemble's }history are about to happen. Like most rural communities denied the luxury of city and town water-borne sewage disposal systems, villagers have had to rely on cesspits, privies, earth closets and (even in the last decade) that modern derivative, the chemical closet. Even the introduction of septic tanks is often made ineffective here by the geological feature of clay overlying the{Kemble {Shelf}limestone outcrop. Now, after the promises of the 1930s and the plans of the 1960s, work will shortly commence on a sewerage system costing almost a million pounds of public money, eliminating the known and potential health hazards for over 200 households and providing the chance for a new development of 50 houses - a minor population explosion.
